MR. J. D. MCLEAN
ASS. DEPUTY & SEC. INDIAN AFFAIRS,
OTTAWA, ONT.

DEAR SIR:

Your favor #151936/5 re repairs done to St. Regis Island school-house, to hand. Mr. Ross drove there yesterday and found out cause of complaint. The roof of the school-house appears to have been leaking and the teacher told him that she had to place pans around the room to catch the water coming through the ceiling which resulted in opening up the latter and then with the extreme heat of the stove of shrinking the timber up again. This also caused the spots on the paint which look very badly. However we will send men down to repair ceiling and repaint all in one coat but in doing so you will have to protect the roof.

Re the protection of the roof — as we have the size of the building and can give you cost of same we beg to herewith submit quotation. We will shingle same with best Cedar shingles laid on felt 4/2" to weather with saddle boards flushing
MR. J. D. MCLEAN ....2........

chimney etc complete with nails, felt, shingles, saddle-boards, delivery of same and furnishing of scaffold (building 20 x 26— about 8 squares of roofing) for the sum of forty-two dollars ($42.00). This you will understand could no doubt be done cheaper if the place were more convenient.

Should you decide to repair roof we will go down either next Saturday or the week following to repair the ceiling— before the ice breaks up.

Yours very truly

Dict. L. A. R.

[Signature]

Ottawa, March 26, 1912.

Sir,

Ross & Co. have agreed to make certain repairs to the interior woodwork of the St. Regis Island School. They state that the building is badly in need of shingling and they have been authorized to do this work. They are to use the best shingles, laid 4½ inches to the weather and the Department is to pay them $42.00 for the work. When it is done they have been instructed to forward their account through your office. Kindly have this submitted, if possible, before the end of the current fiscal year, March 31st.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

F. E. Taillon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, Que.
Ottawa, March 20, 1912.

Gentlemen,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 12th instant in which you advise the Department that it is your intention at an early date to make repairs to the interior woodwork of the school on St. Regis Island. It is to be understood that no expense to the Department will be entailed.

In order to protect this work the Department approves of your suggestion to make further repairs by way of shingling the building and you may do this work when you are remedying the present defects for the sum of $42.00. Your account for this work should be forwarded to the Department through the office of the Indian Agent.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Messrs. Ross & Co.,
Cornwall, Ont.

Sir,

Referring to your of March 20th No. 157936-5, I have enclosed a statement sent me by Ross & Co., and which I cannot possibly recommend for payment.

At the time interior work was being done, the work appeared all right but after a continual fire was kept in the school, the wood naturally commenced to check, owing possibly to green lumber having been used.

Mr. Ross stated that the school looked very badly thus causing the ceiling to be let down. However, in conversation with Miss E. L. Halligan former teacher and Miss M. White the present teacher, I find the roof had leaked in two spots and both within a space of about 3 square feet, hence I am at a loss to see how that could affect the entire work. The roof only looked over six inches while damp.

I am of the opinion that Ross & Co. should not be paid for same.

The shingling seems to be all right but I could not see it all as it was partly covered with snow on Monday last.

J. D. MacLaren,
Allan's Ont.

Your obedient servant,

F. B. Halligan.

Ottawa, April 26, 1912.

Gentlemen,

Referring to your account for $21.22 for repairs to the interior woodwork of the St. Regis Island School-house I beg to say that a letter has been received from the Indian Agent in reference to this account, in which he states that both the former and the present teacher inform him that the roof did leak in two places, but both within a space of about three square feet. Such being the case it is not seen how the generally inferior condition of the interior woodwork could be due to the leaking of the roof, in fact, Miss White, the present teacher, states that the roof only leaked on one occasion since she took charge on the first of October, last. The Agent is of opinion that the checking was possibly owing to lumber that was not sufficiently dried being used.

In view of this report the Department does not consider that it should be called upon to reimburse you for the expenditure incurred in making this job good.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Messrs. Ross & Co.,
Cornwall, Ont.

DEAR SIR:

Re your favor # 151936/5 we beg to state that in our letter to you of April 1st. condition of schoolhouse was exactly as stated. The present teacher represented to me (the writer) the exact nature of leakage in roof of school house as written you; as for the ceiling this too was in the condition stated in our favor of the lst. ultimo. Now we do not ask the Government to assume any responsibility that should be ours and under the circumstances we feel justified in our request. You can readily recognize how quickly a ceiling in wood would bulge and spring from a leakage of this kind—and the writer thinks that the ceiling must have been in a state of dampness right along owing to the condition in which he found the roof, however if you still feel that our claim is not a just one that ends it. We may say further that had the writer not made a personal
examination of this work we might not have been so confident regarding this matter, we are

Yours very truly,

ROSS & CO.

Secretary Dept.
Of Indian Affairs.
Ottawa, Can.

Dear Sir,

I understand, for several years past now, the department has made an allowance, each year, to the amount of ten dollars for each school on the reservation, for the purpose of providing for them little...
presents either at Christmas time or at the end of the term.

I beg to say, I should be very pleased, as well as the children of the St. Regis Island School, may be included in that this year. Hoping to hear from you soon.

Respectfully,

Minnie P. White
Teacher
St. Regis Island Sch.
Ottawa, June 12, 1913.

Madam,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 4th instant in reference to the purchase of prizes for the children attending the St. Regis Island School.

In reply I beg to say that this request should have been made by you through the office of the Indian Agent. To avoid delay, however, you are hereby authorized to expend a sum not exceeding $6.00 in the purchase of suitable prizes, the account to be forwarded to the Department through the office of the Indian Agent, who is being advised of this authority. These prizes should be bought on the Canadian side.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

W.D. McLean

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Teacher,
St. Regis Island School,
St. Regis, Que.
Ottawa, June 12, 1913.

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, September 2, 1913.

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 19th ultimo I beg to say that Mr. Benson of this Department had an interview with Mr. Angus Lalonde in regard to his offer for repairs to the St. Regis Island School and arranged with him to have the following repairs done for the sum of $100.00: outside of building to receive two coats of paint, foundation wall to be pointed and loose stones replaced, coal shed to be tightened up and broken boards replaced, two pieces of scantling to be laid under the eaves close enough to hold the double windows, a step to be placed in front of each of the closets and one pane of glass inserted on the side, the chimney to be mended, the limb of the basswood tree, which is resting on the closet on the east side, to be cut off, a new piece of two inch plank to be placed under the chimney in the school-house as the old one is said to be rotting and a porch of the dimensions mentioned in Mr. Lalonde's offer to be placed at the front entrance.

The Department approves of this amended offer and you may instruct Mr. Lalonde to proceed with the work.

Your obedient servant,

F. E. Taillon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, Que.

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

A teacher's desk is required for the St. Regis Island school. The last desk of this kind purchased for a school on the St. Regis Reserve was bought from A. E. Evans of Cornwall in October, 1913. The price was $11.00, which was reasonable.

They have never had a suitable desk at the St. Regis Island school and I would recommend that one be purchased, as the school is making good progress under Miss McGoey. In case you approve of a desk being supplied from whom should it be purchased?

Ottawa, May 17, 1920.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 10th instant, in which you report that the coal shed and closet in connection with the St. Regis Island Indian Day School are in very poor condition and recommending that a new coal shed and two closets be erected as it would be a big expense to repair and keep the old buildings in proper condition.

I have to request that you will be good enough to furnish an estimate of the cost of erecting separate closets and also the building of a shed to store the fuel. If possible you should give the size of the closets and shed and state approximately the cost of the material and labour required to erect them. If this work can be done at a reasonable cost, the Department will be disposed to have the work done.

The Department has no funds at the present time to consider the erection of a new school building.

Your obedient servant

Ottawa, November 5, 1920.

Sir,

Mr. Inspector Gilman, in his report on his recent inspection of the St. Regis Island Indian Day School, states that some repairs to the building are urgently needed. He states the outhouses are in poor condition and the floor of the school-room is bulged in the middle, making it difficult to walk over.

You should arrange to have the outhouses cleaned and put in good condition and any minor repairs required should be attended to. You should give this matter your early attention. The expense in the matter should be as low as possible. Properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the cost of having the closets cleaned and the repairs made should be forwarded.

With reference to the floor of the school-room I have to request that you will be good enough to furnish a report as to the cost of having the same repaired. You should also give this matter your early attention.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie
For Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir,

In reference to St Regis Island School, I beg to report that a new coal shed will have to be erected this summer; on my next visit I will take the measurements of the old shed so that an estimate can be made.

The school itself, as you are aware, requires repairs; the chimney will have to be rebuilt and the floor has sagged considerably at the north end; owing to the fact that there is no well under the building it is difficult to say just what will be required until an examination has been made which means that during vacation an excavation will have to be made, possibly by putting new stringers in; the floor may be put in its original state; the walls may be in such a state that nothing can be done; however, as soon as school is closed for the holidays, I will have the necessary examination made and report to you.

J.D. McLean, Sec.,
Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Agent
Ottawa, May 31st, 1924.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 20th instant, reporting on the condition of the St. Regis Island Indian Day School building and the need of a new coal shed.

In reply I beg to say that as soon as the school closes for the coming summer holidays you should examine the building and furnish a report as to what repairs are needed to place the same in good condition. You should state the approximate cost of the material and labour required in rebuilding the chimney, repairing the foundation and floor, and in making any other repairs that are required. You should also state what arrangements you can make to have the above repairs carried out. The Department prefers, if possible, that the work be done by day labour under the charge of a competent foreman, you to purchase all material and see that the work is satisfactorily performed.

Regarding the coal shed, you should state the size, the quantity of material required and the cost of the same, as well as the labour.

We will await your report giving the above information which should be furnished as soon as possible after the school closes for the summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

F. H. Baillon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, Que.
Extract from Inspector's Report on the ST. REGIS ISLAND SCHOOL, MAY 27, 1924.

In bad condition. The wood at the back end of the school is quite rotten. The floor inside is sinking at the same end.

A new building will have to be considered.

The shed also is about to fall down.

James Mabon,
Insp.
Ottawa, June 5th, 1924.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the St. Regis Island Indian Day School, draws attention to the condition of the building. He states that the wood at the rear end of the school building has rotted and that the floor inside is sinking. He also states that the shed is about to fall down.

Please examine these buildings and furnish a report as to the repairs you would recommend be carried out to place the same in a serviceable condition, and the approximate cost of any material and labour required. You should furnish this report at an early date, in order that, if it is decided to have any work done, it can be carried out during the coming summer holidays.

While the question of erecting a new building will have to be considered in the near future, the Department has no funds available for this purpose during the present fiscal year.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Aest. Deputy and Secretary.

F. E. Taillon, B.S.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, Que.

Sir:

I beg to say that the following repairs are necessary at St. Regis Island Indian Day School;-

The school desks are unsolid, loose, require tightening by rescrewing. Also inkstand needs new screws.

There is a raise in the floor across class-room, about three inches high, five inches wide. This should be repaired.

Stove-pipes are done. 12 links and 1 elbow are required.

Teachers Residence, St. Regis Village.

The floors in this residence have not been revarnished since building erected in fall of 1927. Varnish badly worn off floors, especially downstairs. In places there is no varnish, other parts where not worn, is fairly good. I consider that these floors should be revarnished.

Delay in not attending to the above matters, only means a heavier expense later.

Kindly advise me regarding the above matters, and if authorized, they may be attended to before the schools reopen.

I am,

Your obedient servant,

Ottawa, July 30, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 26th instant, relative to the repairs that are required at the St. Regis Island Indian Day School and also at the teachers' residence, St. Regis Village.

Relative to the St. Regis Island Indian Day School, you may arrange to have the desks repaired and placed in good condition, and new screws placed in the ink stands. You may also have the floor in the classroom repaired, and you may purchase and have installed the necessary stove pipe. Regarding the revarnishing of the floors in the teachers' residence, St. Regis Village, you may have this work carried out and the floors revarnished with a good grade of varnish. The above work should be completed before the schools reopen after the present summer holidays, and the expense for the purpose should be kept as low as possible.

After the work has been completed, you should forward vouchers, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure for the Island School and teachers' residence at St. Regis Village, separately.

Sir,

Cornwall Island Indian Day School.

I beg to say that the following school supplies are required at Cornwall Island Indian Day School:

4 lbs. Plasticine, blue, red, green and mauve, one pound of each.

One school-room, eight day clock.

With reference to the clock, I beg to say, that there is a Big Ben Clock at this school, but is out of commission, and is not worth repairing. A good reliable eight day clock, can be purchased at Cornwall, Ont. for $8.00 or $10.00, and which I consider is far ahead, than purchasing a Big Ben, which costs $4.50 or $5.00.

I visited above school on October, 28th. The school appears to be running in good order. The attendance is good, with twenty two pupils on the register. All classes are progressing nicely, and a marked advancement is noticed. Mr. Chisholm teacher, reports, that the attendance is regular, with the exception of pupils absent due to sickness.

With reference to vaccinating, I may say that there are three children attending above school, who are not vaccinated, also six children who were vaccinated, about a year ago, that the vaccine did not take effect. I intend making arrangements with Dr. Gardner, of Cornwall, Ont. to visit this school, and vaccinate the children who are not vaccinated.

I am,
Your obedient servant.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,

EXTRACT FROM AGENT McGIBBON ON ST. REGIS ISLAND SCHOOL.

The foundation in this building requires repairs. Stone work is in poor shape; loose and falling away in different places.
Ottawa, March 19, 1930.

Sir,

Referring to your report on the St. Regis Island Indian Day School for the month of February, last, regarding the condition of the foundation of the school building, I have to request that you will forward a full report as to the work required in placing this foundation in a satisfactory condition. You should state how you would propose having the work carried out, giving an approximate estimate of the cost of any material required in having the work done. When we have this information, consideration will be given to authorizing having the necessary repairs carried out when weather conditions permit this coming Spring.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. A. MacGibbon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, P.Q.
St. Regis Island Indian Day School.

The foundation under this school is entirely done. In many places there is no foundation at all. To place this building in shape a new foundation is required, of stone or cement. I would consider cement the best, and almost as cheap. The building should be raised about fifteen inches from the ground. I consulted Mr. Thompson, caretaker of this school, about two weeks ago with respect to this work. Thompson promised to let me know, but has not to date. I expect due to the river breaking up and clearing of ice. As to the cost of this work, I would say that between $70.00 and $80.00 would complete the job. Perhaps Thompson's figure may be lower than that. This is an old building, but by putting a good foundation under it the building would serve for some years yet.
Ottawa, April 16, 1930.

Sir:

With reference to that portion of your letter of the 10th instant regarding the repairs required to the foundation of the St. Regis Indian Day School building, I have to say that the Department will approve of your arranging to have this work carried out.

You may arrange to have the building raised approximately 15 inches from the ground, and a new cement foundation placed under same. You should see that the services of a competent man are engaged to carry out this work; you to purchase the cement and other material required. It is noted you estimate the cost to be approximately $80, and, if possible, this amount should not be exceeded. The Department will leave the matter of the repairs to the foundation of this building in your hands, and will expect you to see that a satisfactory job is completed.

After the work has been completed to your satisfaction, you should forward an account, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of the material supplied and for the labour in having the work carried out.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

W. A. MacGibbon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, P.Q.

Sir,

With reference to attached Voucher No. 1129 in favor of Tom Thomas, for ferrying Miss. Fitzpatrick, teacher to St. Regis Island, I beg to say that on the 9th of January, due to the river partly frozen, and due to rough weather, that I had some difficulty in making arrangements to transfer the teacher to the island. Mr. Thomas and teacher left St. Regis by boat, and were on the river for about an hour, but were obliged to return.

INDIAN AGENT, DATED MAY 6th, 1931.

St. Regis Village school requires a coat of paint outside. It is almost four years since this school was painted. St. Regis Island School should be painted, exterior, also the shed at this school, which was newly built in 1929, should be painted.

These outside jobs could be done by Indians of the reserve. Work is very scarce for Indians of St. Regis reserve, and by giving some painting jobs, would help out some families who are in rather close circumstances.
Ottawa, May 13, 1931.

Sir:

I regret, therefore, that we will have no funds to carry out the redecorating and painting of the above named schools this year.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

On returning to St. Regis after my holidays, I was informed that one of the windows of St. Regis Village Indian Day School was broken.

I visited the school, and found one window glass, large, had been broken, and by all appearances someone had gained entrance, but the interior of the school looked to be undisturbed. Also another large window glass was cracked in two places.

On visiting the village teacher's residence, I discovered that the screening on one of the basement windows had been torn, and a small window glass broken. The interior of the residence appeared to be untouched.

The necessary repairs are being seen to.

Your obedient servant,

Agent.

Sir,

Regarding St. Regis Island Indian Day school, the appearance of the building, both inside and out, could be improved by painting, but this is an old building, or a good cement foundation constructed in 1930. The clapboards are loose and split, the shingles on the roof are in very poor condition, some holes showing, the windows are loose in poor frames, the boarded walls of the interior are full of knots which show through the faded paint.

This building should be re-clapboarded or stuccoed, the windows and frames repaired or new ones put in, the roof reshingled. The wall within a cupboard built underneath the chimney requires plastering.

A few hundred dollars spent on this building would result in an improved building but probably the Department would consider the construction of a new school building, if funds were available.

I hesitate to recommend the spending of too much money on this old building.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs
Indian Agent.
Ottawa.

Ottawa, August 14, 1936.

Dear Sir:

On June 20th, you wrote the Department, with reference to repairs for the St. Regis Island Indian Day School, and on June 26th, you were requested to forward an estimate of the cost of the repairs that are absolutely necessary.

No reply has yet been received to our letter, but the teacher visited the Department today and requested that the interior of the classroom be painted and the desks varnished. Please let me know what it would cost to do this work.

The teacher stated, also, that owing to the condition of the windows, the room is very cold during the winter. Is it possible to make some minor repairs to the windows in order to keep out the cold.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

D. P. McNaughton, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, Que.
Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter regarding painting and repairs to the St. Regis Island School.

The windows will need to be refitted, new strapping for the window sash and for the doors, at approximate cost, including labour and cartage $10.00.

Regarding the painting of the interior. The walls and ceiling (constructed in a half circle) are of T & G lumber and I judge one coat of paint would be an improvement to the appearance of the class room, if a second is necessary it could be done later.

I have had John Day look over this room and he will do the painting for approximately $8.00, paint to be supplied at estimated cost of $9.00.

Anticipating your approval I am having Charles Seymour repair the windows and doors but will await your written permission to undertake the painting, which would need to be done after the windows etc. are repaired.

I am having this mailed today so as to receive a reply soon.

Your obedient Servant,

D.F. McNaughton
Indian Agent,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, August 22, 1936.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 20th instant, regarding the painting and repairs required at the St. Regis Island Indian Day School. It is noted that you have arranged to have the repairs required to the windows and doors carried out and that the approximate cost, including labour and cartage, will be $10.00.

It is noted that you have obtained a price of approximately $5 from John Day for the painting of the interior. You may arrange for the purchase of the paint required, at an estimated cost of $9. I would request that you have the repairs to the windows and doors and the painting carried out at the earliest possible date, in order not to interfere with the classroom work.

Sir:

I have to advise that No. 609 Tom Thomas, who ferries Miss Fitzpatrick to the St. Regis Indian Day school has applied for an increase in compensation allowed, from 40¢ per twice per school day, trip to 75¢ per school day, and 40¢ per round trip. Thomas pointed to the fact that he has to hold himself available for the daily trips which bars him from securing a more remunerative daily occupation. He augments his earnings by occasional trips to Cornwall and other parts of the Reservation.

I would wish to recommend that this Indians application be given favourable consideration. He has to row a distance of approximately ¼ of a mile to the Island, through seasonably rough weather and ice conditions. I will be noted that this is a necessary service.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,

Dear Sir:

Re: St. Regis Island School

While it had been planned to make allowances for the building of a new school in the Estimates for 1941 it does not now appear that this would receive favourable consideration in view of present conditions.

The roof of the above school is in very bad condition and it is thought that if funds were made available for shingling that this would put the school in fair shape for a few years or until such time as the present building could be replaced by a new one.

The attached requisition covers material required for this purpose and while the labour is only an estimate it is just possible that this item can be reduced somewhat.

Your approval of attached requisition is urgently requested.

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,

Dear Sir:

An expenditure for labour is also approved, provided Indians will be employed. If it is necessary to employ white men, you should let me know, in order that I may advise you whom you should hire.

Dear Sir:

Re: Cornwall Island E.School

It has been found necessary to have a complete set of grates installed in the furnace of above school. The old grates have been completely burned out and of no further use.

Dear Sir:

I find it necessary to seek authority for the purchase of a heater for use at the St. Regis Island Indian Day School.

About six years ago a number of heaters were purchased for our schools. These heaters had a cast iron fire-box. Already the heater in the Sr. Room of the village school has had to be replaced and a similar situation has arisen at St. Regis Ild. The cast firebox has become cracked in several places and while it has been patched up on different occasions I fear that this will not serve much longer as new breaks are showing.

I would ask authority to purchase a new heater, if such is obtainable, and if not, that permission be given without delay for the purchase of a rebuilt heater.

St. Regis, Que.
Sept. 18th, 1944.

R. A. Hoey, Esq. Supt. Welfare & Training.

An inspection of the St. Regis Isl. Day School discloses that the following urgent repairs are required as well as materials listed.

The window sash is in such a state of decay that they will no longer hold the glass in place; new window frames are needed as well, as the building is very old and it is impossible to install new sash in the old frames which are reminiscent of the "square nail era". The fact that storm windows were never on this school has not helped matters any and these should be supplied as well. The building has a cement casement around it with no air outlet with the result that, so far as is visible, the north end of the school is sagging due to dewayed sills. The recent earthquake, of course, has provided many air outlets in the cement casing and has not helped in the general condition of the building. The floor needs repairs as the centre is convexed to a point about II inches. A new chimney will have to be built.

I am not aware whether or not it is the Department's intention to build a new school on St. Regis Island. One is badly needed and has been for a number of years. I would like to have your opinion on this school as I hesitate to make such repairs if it is the intention to construct a new school in the very near future. If such is not the intention however, these repairs will have to be made this Fall. I would like to know your intention by return mail as the windows and frames will have to be made at the factory and I am going to have a hard time getting the order through. If too much delay is not experienced I believe I can get a carpenter locally to do the work, i.e., installing frames, etc., and raising the N.end of the building and putting in a new sill. A list is enclosed showing our requirements for above.

T.L. Bonnah, Agent.
Ottawa,
September 21, 1944.

Mr. T.L. Bonnah, Indian Agent, St. Regis, Que.

In order that the work may be done before the cold weather the Department approves local purchase of the articles shown on the attached requisition. It is noted from the latter part of your letter that you are able to secure a carpenter to do the work.

REPORT ON ST. REGIS INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OCTOBER, 1944.

Considerable repairs are being made at the St. Regis Island Day School. New windows and window frames are being installed complete with storm windows and a new chimney has been built. Previously, no storm windows were on this school, with the result that the fixed windows had been so weatherbeaten that they would no longer hold the lights. The old chimney which was constructed in the interior of the building and had become unsafe due to the earthquake, was torn down and the new chimney erected on the exterior. Repairs were also made to the floor of the classroom to remove a disconcerting hump. It is hoped that through this operation, both teacher and students will be able in future to maintain a more even keel. It was necessary, to replace the sills at the rear of the building, as between dry rot and the squirrels, very little of the old sill was left. It seems reasonable to assume that when repairs are completed, the building should be at least 80% warmer.

To provide some recreational facilities for the children in the village, some ploughing and levelling was done so that we could operate a skating rink this year. A small amount of sports equipment has been purchased to date.

T.L. Bonnah,

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF INSPECTOR THIBAULT,

ST. REGIS ISLAND SCHOOL

A very old building, sills in very bad shape and should be replaced as well as the floor.
Ottawa, June 25, 1945.

Mr. T. L. Bonnah, Indian Agent,
St. Regis, Que.

Inspector Thibault has reported
that the sills and the floor of the St. Regis
Island Indian Day School should be replaced.

I realize this is an old
building, but at the same time you know that
it is impossible to erect a new one this year.
Would it be possible to carry out the repairs
suggested by Inspector Thibault? If so, you
should obtain an estimate of the cost and let
me know if you can have the work done during
the summer holidays.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
I wish to refer to your letter of June 23 regarding Inspector Thibault's report on the condition of the St. Regis Island Indian Day School.

I am quite in agreement with the Inspector's recommendation, but to replace the sills and floor of this school will require considerable amount of work and material. As stated in your letter, this is a very old building and it is difficult to say just what trouble we will run into when we start to raise the building. As you know, last year we put in new windows and storm sashes and also built a new chimney on the outside, and had some repairs made to the floor. Due to the impossibility of obtaining skilled help for this kind of a job, the work will have to be left in abeyance. Again, there is very little use in going to such an expense as outlined in your letter unless the entire building is sheeted on the outside as well. If it is the intention to continue using this school, then as soon as help, materials, and money are available, the inside of the building could be sheeted with Ten-Test and painted, a new floor laid, new sills under the building, and the building jacked up on a foundation, and have the outside sheeted with featheredge. We would then have as good a school as we could possibly want with the small attendance on that island.

Enclosed please find a requisition of School Materials for Chenail School; St. Regis Island and St. Regis Village Schools at St. Regis Agency.

With regards to the requisition for St. Regis Island School, I will observe a requisition for a heating and cooking stove which is required in the teachers' residence. In this connection I might point out that the teachers' residence comprises two rooms in a private home on St. Regis Island. It is, at present, heated by a very small Leroy cook stove. This stove is too small to hold a coal fire until the teacher gets home from school with the result that the place is quite often cold. I think that to put a larger stove in such a small place would be going to extremes. Some months ago I discussed this matter with Mr. Doucet and suggested that a 3-burner Perfection oil stove with an oven be supplied for cooking purposes. Also that a small capacity oil burner (Duo-Therm or otherwise) be supplied to be used in case of necessity. Under this way the heating requirements would be taken care of and the temperature could be controlled according to the wishes of the teacher. There is a possibility that a type of heating and cooking combination oil stove exists and if so, possibly this would suffice. Also it might be possible to install burners in the present cook stove. You might advise me in this regard.

Regarding the requisition for the St. Regis School Junior and Senior Rooms, articles are requested for sewing classes and an allowance of $30.00 for materials under the heading of Domestic Science. I am given to understand that more stress will be placed upon this phase of education in the coming year. There are also some articles I have ticked off in the pencil which may not be considered as necessities. No doubt the chest of drawers could be made good use of for storage purposes.

T. L. Bonnah,

- 2 gallons of light ivory
- 2 gallons of cream
- 1 gallon of brown trim.

OTTAWA, 27th June, 1899

The Secretary:

Miss Katharine Hughes of 253 Concession St., Ottawa, has applied for the position of teacher of the St Regis school, which is now closed.

The late teacher, Mr Pirie resigned his position on the 31st March last, and on the recommendation of Mr Agent Long no successor was appointed. As matters on the St Regis Reserve have quieted down to a considerable extent, the school might be re-opened at an early date, but before doing so it would be necessary to obtain a properly qualified teacher. Miss Hughes, the present applicant was first brought to the notice of the Department by the Hon David Laird, Indian Commissioner at Winnipeg, who recommended her in connection with a vacancy at Couchiching.

Miss Hughes holds a first class teaching certificate from the Normal School at Prince Edward Island and has had some experience in an Indian school, having taught on the Garden River Reserve. She is a Roman Catholic and a niece of Archbishop O'Brien of Halifax. She refers to Mr Prendergast, Separate School Inspector, for recommendation as to her capability and fitness for the position.

Miss Hughes who has called once or twice at the office, appears to be bright and intelligent and very
very much interested in Indian education, and should make a capable and energetic teacher.

The school on the St Regis Reserve has been most unsatisfactory for some years, and although the late teacher was fully qualified, he failed to make a success of it, owing, I have no doubt to the unsettled state of mind of the Indians. The children are all backward in their studies, and I think that a change to a lady teacher might be beneficial.

Martin Beards

There was a Xmas tree at the village school and its the first one ever held, it took well and the teacher deserves credit the way she had the children so well trained in so short a time, the parents was delighted to hear the children sing, something they never heard before. There were five chiefs present also the priest and Agent Long, was there. Mr. Agent Long made a few remarks, the school-house was crowded. It was held in the afternoon. I think it will make a good impression to the parents so that they will send their children regular to school.
My dear Mrs. Benson,

I should very much like to have formal permission to dismiss my junior class, about thirteen (13) in all, at half past eleven in the morning and half past three in the afternoon. With two exceptions the ages of these children range from six to eight years.

I was so dissatisfied with the attendance that I made a trial of early dismissals this week. It has been a decided success—the average attendance moved by three, better order in school, more willing work and all say they like it better. The parents seem to approve of it too.

The attendance today was 24.

The regular pupils have been studying as closely as they could all winter and I should like to have this relaxation allowed the little ones, as they have only 15 minutes recess twice a day.

With the earnest hope that this will meet with your favorable consideration,

Your very sincerely,

From the returns going in with this copy will see that the children have been attending very well without the inducement of a Christmas tree. I expect a decided increase in the number of girls after Easter. Many of them have been keeping at home since they had that little gift in January. The children seem very much interested in the talks on tuberculosis. I think we should have a set of lessons in very simple English prepared to fit for our Indian schools. I shall try it with my pupils, at least.

The children are growing very ambitious to imitate the scholars in the outside world. Several of the older boys would like to go away to school to learn trades.
The girls have a Sunshine Society with fortnightly evenings at my boarding-house.

The Dry Temperance League has begun to attract the elders—partly because of its jolly outside meetings. They began with a supper and evening with me, and I could not have found a more sentimentally set of little fellows in Canada, or more at their ease. There were only eleven of them there.

We accept invitations to the boys' homes in turn now, and we have a negro minstrel and comedy actors' troupe I can repeat each evening, from seven until nine o'clock. The little farces are written up between us and the dialogue is in English. Sometimes we play games, in English too, and always have a five minute talk on Temperance. I wish I could see a gymnasium and card-playing club room for the young men here, with pictures and books and music. They are crazy about these things. I believe they'd win the field from the saloons. It is good only to see these people laugh at the boys' troubles.

I do not expect to go up to Ottawa for Easter but I should be glad if my cheque came early. Sometimes it is well in coming. If she has not forgotten her doctor's day, I hope that he shall be kind & see her at any time. She was here to run in April.

Ottawa, April 28, 1906.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

On March 31, last, Miss Nolan, teacher of the St. Regis Indian school, was notified that her services would not be required after June 30, next. The reason for dispensing with her services is, that the school has made no progress during the time she has been in charge, since September, 1906.

Miss Nolan's qualifications are sufficient, but she has given no evidence her ability to interest the Indians in the school. Mr. Inspector Ramsden, who visited St. Regis in November, last, reported that he found only seven children in attendance, where he considered there should be an average of 25 or 30. He also found the out-buildings in a very filthy condition.

Mr. Cook, of this Department, who was at St. Regis on official business lately, found only six children present at the school when he called, although it was an exceedingly fine day.

I know of no Indian school which would afford a better opportunity for a zealous teacher to obtain tangible results. The children all live in the immediate neighborhood of the school and their parents are fairly well-to-do and there is good accommodation for a teacher.

The
The Department pays a salary of $350, which is a high salary compared with public schools in the province of Quebec and a much more active teacher could and should be obtained for the money. Miss Nolan is apparently content to let matters drift along quietly and draw her salary. This might do for a white school but to make a success of an Indian school it is necessary to have a live teacher. Scholarship does not count so much as energy and earnestness.

I notice in Miss Nolan's letters to the Department that she refuses to accept her dismissal without cause and explanation. She has had ample notice and if we wish to make anything of this school a change of teachers would seem to be necessary.

Some years ago the school on St. Regis Island and at the Chenail were closed, with the idea that the children would attend the village school. This scheme has not worked up to the present, owing to the difficulty in their transport, their parents naturally objecting to allowing small children to cross the channels in boats. This might be overcome by arranging with the Dundee ferry to convey the children night and morning to and from St. Regis, if there were a good school there, but this is another story, which will be dealt with on the St. Regis Island file.

GENERAL REPORT

OF

INSPECTOR A. I. GILMAN

FOR THE

SCHOOL YEAR 1911-1912
Sir,

I have the honour to forward you my annual report.

TERRITORY.

My district of inspection comprises the counties of Huntingdon, Beauharnois, Chateauguay, Soulange, Vaudreuil, Napierville, Laprairie and parts of Missisquoi and St. Johns.

I also inspect the Indian schools at St. Régis, Yellow Island and Chenail under the Federal Government.

Two of the Indian schools are taught by Indian women or squaws as they are called by the natives; about 150 Indian pupils attend these schools and they are doing very satisfactory work.

The school-houses and out-houses are in excellent condition and well furnished with modern equipment. A fine new building was erected at St. Régis village last year. The Indian agent, Mr. Taillon, is enforcing, in a local way, a compulsory educational law. On the day of my last visit, a very stormy day, 42 pupils were present. The children are well clothed, neat, and everything extremely tidy. They all speak the Indian language, but read and recite their lessons in good English. Another Indian school will be erected at Sugar Bush Island next year.

All the schools of my district except one, were in operation during the year. No qualified teacher could be secured for the salary offered and the commissioners did not care to engage a person without proper qualifications. Higher remuneration will be offered next year—and, no doubt, the pupils
will have the advantage of a good school, under the tuition of a qualified teacher.

EXAMINATION.

Written and oral examinations were held and certificates of standing awarded; written reports were sent to the commissioners and trustees. The general proficiency of the schools was higher during the year than any previous year. Arithmetic, which has been weak during the past six years was fairly satisfactory—averaging sixty-one per cent over the whole district, a gain of eleven per cent over last year, and nine per cent over any one of the past six years.

ATTENDANCE.

I am sorry to report a small loss in the average attendance during the past year. I am also sorry to have to report a continual decrease in the number enrolled in the different municipalities. I am of the opinion that the decrease in the number attending the rural schools is general throughout the English portion of the Province.

CLASSIFICATION.

The municipalities are classified according to the regulations prescribed by the Educational Department, for proficiency of the pupils, qualification of the teachers, salaries paid, condition and equipment of the buildings and grounds.

EXCELLENT.

St. Joachim de Beauharnois, Howick, St. Chrysostome, Godmanchester, Ormstown, Elgin and Hinchinbrook in part.

GOOD.

Franklin, Havelock, Dundee, St. Thomas, Lacolle, L'Acadie and St. George de Clarenceville in part, Hemmingford.

MEDIUM.

The remaining municipalities.

UNSATISFACTORY.

None this year, unless I mention St. Urbain and St. Constant (in Laurier) which are improving.

SCHOOL-HOUSES.

Most of the buildings are in a very satisfactory condition and fairly well equipped.

There are no regular libraries and few reference books or Encyclopaedias.

There are a few supplementary readers and a few odd books donated by the Department. A couple of sets of books supplied by the association of Protestant teachers are in circulation.

They form a small circulating library and are placed in charge of the inspector who is responsible for the circulation.

TAXATION.

The school taxes are generally low in my district of inspection—ranging from two to six mills and the fees from five to twenty-five cents per capita a month. Many of the school boards visit their schools once a year, some make two visits a year and a few do not make any efforts to encourage their schools or teachers. It is usually the poor municipalities which are neglected.

THE ACCOUNTS.

The secretary-treasurers keep their accounts well and have their books annually audited.

TEACHERS.

The teachers have been faithful to their charges, anxious to advance their pupils and diligent in their work. A very excellent class of young people were placed in charge of the schools of my district last year and excellent work has been done.

I regret to state that there were employed in my district, five young girls, who had neither diplomas nor the proper qualification to enable them to obtain them through service.

Permission from the Department was obtained to engage them.
We hope to eliminate this class from our ranks as soon as possible. We do not want them, and hope the Government will take steps to extend the possibilities of the Normal School training so as to reach young people who are anxious to teach but have not the means to qualify. It is difficult to secure qualified teachers for the salaries now offered in some municipalities.

Many of the young teachers who have passed grade II academy and have regular permits are doing excellent work but they lack the confidence of trained teachers who have had the advantages of a year or two at Macdonald College.

CONFERENCES.

The usual annual conferences were held in ten local centres and they were attended by nearly all the teachers of my district of inspection. A few of the commissioners and secretaries also attended. At Humington the local member, Mr. W. H. Walker, addressed the teachers in the morning, and commissioner Dr. Clouston and the local clergyman in the afternoon.

RETIRED TEACHERS.

I called on the retired teachers residing in my district and made a report of the state of their health to the Department. One of the pioneers of education in this Province passed away during the past year—Mr. Ringland, of Hudson, after a long and painful illness. The late Mr. Ringland was one of nature's gentlemen, gentle, kind, generous, a lover of sports and vigorous exercises, but a close student of literature and of men. Unlike most schoolmasters, he saw the bright side of life even in his declining years.

BONUSES.

Bonuses were awarded as usual, but no honour cards, as none were received for distribution.

Prizes were awarded to the four municipalities which made the greater efforts towards improvement during the year. Both lists were published in the local newspapers.

GENERAL.

Gradual improvement is being made in all the departments of education, better school-houses, better equipment, better salaries and consequently better teachers. We expect to be able in a short time to have every school taught by a Normal School graduate of experience. Commissioners and trustees have generally ceased trying to secure their neighbour's daughters as teachers, because they can reside at home and teach for very small salaries. A short time ago it was quite common to find young girls teaching without diplomas or permits in our best schools. We are happy to report that this condition does not prevail any longer. We expect to find every school next year taught by a qualified teacher. Our salaries range from $200 to $375 per annum, a higher average than on any previous year.

BULLETINS.

The Educational Department has received during the year bulletins of inspection from each municipality, for each district, containing statistical information for every school, also comments and recommendations made by the inspector while in the different districts.

These bulletins and recommendations together with the report are respectfully submitted.

I have the honour, etc.,

A. LUTHER GILMAN,
School Inspector.

Memorandum: Mr. Redley.

Acting on instructions I left Ottawa on Monday, the 17th instant, for St. Regis going by way of Hogansburg.

I went down to the reserve and called on Mr. Agent Tallon who accompanied me to the Village School which is in charge of Miss Gallagher. We found 25 children in attendance, 18 boys and 11 girls. They were put through their regular exercises and the work compared very favourably with that done by the Indian children at the school on the American side of the reserve which I visited. The reading was loud and distinct and, although the pupils are not generally very far advanced, they are getting on as well as can be expected considering the irregular attendance.

The new school building is well situated, but the yard wants a few loads of gravel to level it off and the school should be repainted. A new fence is required. I found that the plaster on the inside of the building is shrinking from the window and door frames and is loose in some parts. I think that a poor job was made of this part of the work. There is an immense box stove in the room which smokes occasionally and was smoking when I was there, caused by the pipes being higher over the stove than at the chimney. The wind carried away the cap of the
the chimney and loosened some of the bricks. I advised Mr. Taillon to have the caps replaced on the chimney, the chimney mended and the pipe lowered.

Miss Gallagher is a capable teacher, but she is very unpopular with the Indians; so much so that they have made several complaints as to her harsh treatment of the children and the indiscreet remarks made to them. It was chiefly on account of these complaints that I was sent to St. Regis. I advised Miss Gallagher of the purpose of my visit and told her to be present at the Agent's office at three o'clock on the following afternoon.

The two chiefs of the St. Regis Band, the parents who made the complaints against Miss Gallagher and the truant officer as well as Miss Gallagher were present in the Agent's office on Tuesday afternoon. The Indians claimed that Miss Gallagher used undue severity in punishing the children. Mrs. Hopps, who is a sister of the Priest and married an Indian, stated that her little girl was so severely punished that her arms were black and blue. Joe Smoke stated that she nearly tore the ear off his son's head and John Jacobs stated that his daughter was badly hurt. Several others made similar complaints. They also stated that when the children left the school-room for any purpose the door was shut and they were kept out in the cold until such time as she saw fit to let them in. They complained of the coldness of the school-room and stated that when reproving the children for any faults she used very insulting language. Chief Jacobs and Chief Jake Fire made long harangues in Indian, which were interpreted. These went
went to show that Miss Gallagher's treatment of the children was too harsh and that they had always received kind treatment from the other teachers who had been in charge of the school previous to her engagement and they demanded her instant dismissal.

Miss Gallagher, when called upon, denied the charges, although she admitted that in order to maintain discipline she found it necessary to correct the children sometimes with the strap. She said she never used a stick or a ruler.

The Priest told me that he had seen the black and blue marks on the wrists of his niece and that Miss Gallagher was altogether too severe with the children.

I endeavoured to arrive at an amicable settlement of the trouble and the chiefs agreed to Miss Gallagher's remaining on till the 30th of June on condition that she would be more gentle in her ways and Miss Gallagher agreed to this arrangement. I am afraid, however, that the chiefs will persist in their demand for a change after that date, as Miss Gallagher is, as before said, unpopular with the villagers. They are very ready to take offence and seem to be annoyed at her ways. She informed me that it is impossible for her to get a suitable lodging in the village and they attribute her living in Hogansburg to her pride. Although she is a devout Roman Catholic she attends the church in Hogansburg and I think the Priest is annoyed at her for doing so. As far as I can make out the whole trouble appears to be that the Indians do not want a white teacher on the reserve. Jacobs is a very domineering man and he has a niece who was
educated in the United States, whom he would like to have placed in charge of the St. Regis School. All the other teachers on the reserve are Indians and none of them have certificates. Mr. Taillon, who lives in the village and understands the Iroquois thoroughly, does not place much reliance on the complaints. He says that Miss Gallagher is attentive and competent and wishes to have a good school with regular attendance and good discipline and that she receives little or no encouragement, although all the Indians admit she is a good teacher. The Indians, while agreeing to let bygones be bygones, demand a change after the summer holidays.

I am of opinion that the Indians will never take kindly to Miss Gallagher and I would suggest that she be transferred to some other school. There was no case made against her that would call for her dismissal and I am sure that she would be glad of a change. I may say here that the Agent, who saw Mrs. Hopps' child, failed to find any marks on her.

I was not able to go to the St. Regis Island School, but I saw Miss White, the teacher, on the 16th, who told me that she has thirteen children present on that day and that she had had a very fair attendance all through the winter. Miss White is an Indian girl who was educated at the Carlyle Institute and who, Mr. Agent Taillon, tells me, is doing very well.
Tuesday, 18th March. -- Mr. Agent Taillon and I drove down to the lower Chenail to look for a suitable site for the proposed new school at the East end of the reserve. After examining several locations along the road we came to the conclusion that the best one for the new school building would be on the lot just purchased for the St. Regis Indians known as lot number three, on the Cadastral plan. This location is well adapted for school purposes, as it is convenient to the river road and is high and dry, would accommodate all the Indians who are too far from the present Chenail School. Some of the Indians were present when we looked over the grounds and they were satisfied that it would be the most suitable place for the school. There a few Indians living at Sugarbush Island, who would be quite near enough to attend, as well as some of the Indians living on the lower end of the Yellow Island.

A school site of suitable dimensions could be laid out when the surveyor is sent to survey the land.
On our return we called on the Chenail School which is charge of Mrs. Sarah Back. I found 26 children present: 13 boys and 13 girls. The school room has a seating capacity for only 36 and there are 51 children on roll. If the new school is built it will relieve this one, as many of the children would be able to attend it.

Mrs. Back is doing good work and is popular with the Indians. I found the room was very drafty and I recommend that the building should be provided with double windows before the next winter sets in. A map of Province Quebec should be sent them as the one they have is in French and the teaching is in English.

I drove back to Hogansburg where we had dinner and after that went back to the village.

On Wednesday the 19th. I went to Cornwall and had dinner, and crossed the bridge to Uscam and went down to Miss Roundpoint's school. There were 32 pupils present: 19 boys and 13 girls. The room, considering the conditions of the roads was clean and comfortable.
The seating accommodation was for 36 pupils. The school is well supplied with material. The children seemed bright and intelligent. I examined the classes, the senior pupils did well; their reading was loud and distinct and they understood what they read. Both Mrs. Back and Miss Roundpoint had good control of their pupils and are well liked by both pupils and parents.

The Cornwall Island School Building will need some slight repairs, painting the foundation and ceiling, but these can be done in the summer holidays. I noticed some broken panes of glass, the agent should be asked to see that the slight repairs be attended to.

A little boy named Lawrence White who is in Miss Roundpoint's school asked to be taken to Ottawa. I made inquiries and found that his father had left his wife. The mother works when she can but does not bear a very good character, and the boy is certainly a bright little fellow and should be given a chance.
There is another little boy in the school named Robert Jacobs who is similarly situated. He is only eight years old and his case is deserving consideration. Another application was made by a widow named Jacobs for her little boys to be placed in the orphanage here. She has two children there already and three at home. Should the department feel inclined to do anything for these children it could on the usual terms: $60.00 a year and clothes.

I found Mr. Taillon most obliging and I consider him a very efficient Agent. He is young and energetic and has a fair knowledge of the language of the Indians, knows them well and is highly thought of by them. He showed me over his house which has been repaired on the inside with the exception of the cellar, which should have a drain and would be better with a concrete floor, as it was wet when I was there. There are also some slight repairs to be made to the outbuildings and I think if he were furnished with the lumber he would have them done.

Mr. Taillon has charge of about 1600 Indians and...
and is one of the few Agents who live on the reserve. You can understand that living in the village he is constantly called upon by the Indians. He tells me that his salary from this Department is only $250.00 a year and, although he holds the positions of custom house officer and post master, his total receipts from these three sources of revenue only amount to $755.00. His work in connection with the Indians is the most exacting and when you consider the duties he performs I think that in all fairness he should have a substantial increase.

Mr. Taillon told me that he wished the Department would let him have a telephone, as in case of sickness he has no readier means of communicating with the doctor than by mail or driving to Hogansburg to phone him.

I noticed that the American government had built a most up-to-date road from the Indian reserve on their side of the border and as soon as you cross the line you can at once tell that you are on the Canadian side by the condition of the roads.

A day or two before I was at St. Regis a violent cyclone struck this section of the country, breaking off pine trees, overturning outbuildings and causing slight damage in the village, striking the school and the church.
The church suffered considerably, as there were a number of slates torn off the roof and a great many panes of glass broken. The Indians were anxious to have the roof of the church repaired out of their funds.

There was no sickness on any portion of the reserve at the time of my visit and the Indians seem to be fairly well off, especially those who were working their own lands. I was told that the Cornwall Island Indians obtained first prize for butter at the Cornwall fair and more of the village Indians could be placed on land to their advantage as there is no regular employment for them there.

To The Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Gentlemen:

We respectfully call to your attention, and for your consideration the following facts.

Jacob Bay, an Indian of the St Regis Band, Mohawk tribe, drawing annuities and owning land at St. Regis, has been sending his nine year old son to the school situated on the reservation.

It being considered essential to his financial interests, that he keep his boy out of the school at times, he did so.

Later when things had become somewhat settled, he sent the boy to school. The boy was sent back home and told that he could not attend the reservation school. The father again sent the boy to school, and again the boy was sent home. A third time the boy was sent to the school, and again the boy was sent home.

Your agent Mr. Taillon told me that the trouble has been existing for about two years, and that Mr. Bay was under the impression that he could send the boy to school when he chose.

The father has some land on the American side of the reservation and is "working" that land. Mr. Taillon holds that as he does not live on the Canada side of the line, that he cannot send his boy to the Canadian school.
He also holds that he has no authority to allow the boy to go to the Canadian school.

In view of the fact that the Indians in question ARE WARDS OF THE DOMINION OF CANADA, and not of the UNITED STATES, This Council takes the stand that the boy belongs in the Canadian school, and should not be deprived of an education because of so trivial a dispute.

The father has been instructed that he MUST send the boy to school regularly, as, to send him at intervals only, would be a great trouble to the teacher and would tend to set the boy back with his studies.

The father, agreed to send the boy to school regularly, and that in the presence of Mr. Taillon and several of our Council members, yet your agent tells us that he has no authority to allow the boy to go to the school while the father resides on the American side of the line.

Inconsistent as it may seem, he also tells us that he has previously allowed the boy to go to the Canadian school while the father resided on the U.S. side. Mr. Taillon also informed me that he bore no malice toward Mr. Bay. If Mr. Taillon had authority to allow the boy to go to the school under the circumstances before, why has he not that authority now?

It is our belief that favoritism is being shown on the reservation, and that there exist irregularities that require the attention of the Department of Indian Affairs.

Investigation reveals the fact that large quantities of alcoholic liquors are being consumed by some of the Indians on the reservation,
I am personally informed that Mr. Taillon's father sells whisky to the Indians, and that when Mr. Taillon asks Indians where they got their liquor, and they answer that they purchased the same from Mr. Taillon's father, that he does not take the liquor from them. But, if they say that they purchased the whisky at Cornwall, that he does take the liquor from them.

These matters and many other, can be settled by your Office, and I hope that you will give them your prompt attention as the Council has authorized me to engage counsel to take to the courts many cases that are considered irregular. I wish to avoid as much litigation as possible, but in many instances I am convinced that the wrongs are so glaring that publicity is necessary.

Some time ago I suggested that it would be good policy to send an investigating representative from your Office to St. Regis reservation to look into the affairs of the people on the reservation. I repeat that in my opinion it would be best that your Office do so at once.

This will be all for this time, wishing you

Good cheer, and clear insight to the end that the work of God, Clean Justice and Humanity may proceed smoothly.

Chief Thunderwater

P.S. Carbon copy of this letter has been forwarded to Mr. Taillon at the reservation, that he may know just what we are doing. It is my policy never to do anything behind a person's back unless I am dealing with a wanton rogue.

Dear sir:-

It has become necessary that we call to your attention the fact that many of the children in the school presided over by Miss Nellie Keon at the St. Regis reservation Canada have been cruelly beaten for the reason that they, in compulsory obedience to the call of nature, have either wet their clothing or upon the floor of the school when they could no longer hold their urine.

It is, as you are well aware not the present custom to beat children in the public schools for any reason whatsoever. It is very cruel and unjust to refuse children the privilege of attendance to the natural physical call and especially so to abuse them when out of common decency they covertly free themselves of the by-products of nature.

The use of clubs and sticks must be abolished in the schools in Canada as well as they have long since been abolished in the United States. There can be no objection to the using of a light strap on the children when incorrigible, but it cannot be called incorrigibility when children ask to be excused for the reason set forth and are refused.

It is in my opinion useless to appeal to the Agent Mr. Taillon in any matter pertaining to anything that is detrimental to the wishes of Miss Keon, as it is obvious to many that he and she are fast friends: So much so is this a fact that as I have reported to The Department several months ago, She instructs the children to especially pray for Mr. Taillon, and tells the innocent children that he(Taillon) "Is an angel".

I am sending for your consideration the inclosed letter as to the beating of the boy of Jake Fire over the back of the hand until the finger nails would stick out at the nails. Would such treatment hurt Mr. Taillon?

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of yours of November 17th instant, in which you communicate the reception of a complaint against Miss Keon from Chief Thunderwater alleging that some of the pupils have been severely dealt with by her.

I must say that such a communication is only a tissue of falsehoods, as Miss Keon has always proved to be very cautious, conscientious and careful of her pupils welfare; I know that she would not punish any of her pupils severely as she has too high a regard for them.

There has not been made to me any complaint against Miss Keon, this claim by John Kerr or anyone else, and this complaint came as a very great surprise to me.

I may say quite conclusively that on Nov. 18th, 1915, John Kerr accompanied by his grandson Jake arrived, called at the office complaining that Miss Keon had severely punished the boy. I asked him to show me how badly injured the boy was.

was, and to my surprise and delight, he examined one hand and then the other but could not show any trace of a severe punishment. Sir,

I desire to make application for an increase of salary to Miss Willie Keon, the present incumbent of the St Regis mission school, under whose able and efficient guidance, so far in the management of her work during the three years past.

I have received your letter dated [date] regarding the complaints of the parents who have placed their children in our school. I understand that you are concerned about the condition of the school and the lack of proper facilities.

Mr. Scott,

Miss McGrath states that she is taking a correspondence course in order to obtain a higher grade certificate.

As long as the bonus at the present rate is continued I would consider that Miss McGrath is receiving a good salary for her work, which is in excess of that paid to most of the other teachers in Quebec by this Department and is the equal to that paid to the teachers in the provincial rural schools of Quebec.

Crime report.

Re:-Assault of School Teacher at St Regis Reserve (ue).

Re:-Mrs John L. Thompson (Indian) charged with Assault.

On Jan 27th, I received instructions from Det.Sergt Ramsay, to go to St Regis Reserve (ue), and investigate the above case.

On January 28th, accompanied by Sergt.No.7992 Constable Tahamont, I left Ogdensburg Station (N.Y.) & traveled, for Syamsburg N.Y., at 6:15 A.M., arriving at Hogansburg N.Y., at 10:42 A.M. We took Auto to Hogansburg N.Y., and put up at the Murphy Hotel; After lunch we proceeded to St Regis (ue), distance about three miles, and interviewed Mr Taillon, Indian Agent, who stated the particulars of the case in question. We then interviewed Miss Gertie Legarde, school teacher of the St Regis Village School, also Miss Brown another school teacher of the same school, who witnessed what took place; after hearing their statements of what happened, I came to the conclusion to learn information and communicate with one Mrs John L. Thompson, an Indian, who, on the 24th day of January 1921, did enter the school house in the Village of St Regis (ue), between the hours of 3:00 and 4:00 P.M. on said date, and assault one Miss Gertie Legarde, school teacher, by catching hold of said Miss Gertie Legarde and striking her.

After making out the Warrant for her arrest, Mr Taillon, Indian Agent, thought that it would be better if we would have the case taken before a Magistrate, stating that he thought that it would have more of a moral effect on this party, and the Indians in general; he suggested that we take Mrs John L. Thompson before Mr John Macmillan, at Dundee (ue), who is in the same County as St Regis Village, which is a distance of 12 miles from St Regis (ue), and would be nearer than Cornwall, as the only way of crossing the river was quite away down.

On January the 29th, at 8:30 A.M., I left Hogansburg N.Y., accompanied by Constable Tahamont, in his Uniform, and went to St Regis Village where we went to the house of Mrs John L. Thompson and placed her under arrest; and accompanied by Miss Gertie Legarde and Miss Brown we proceeded to Dundee (ue).

Mr MacMillan tried this case under Section 29, after hearing the evidence, he found the accused guilty, sentenced her to pay a Fine of $20.00 and $2.00 each month in Goal at Valleyfield (ue); The Fine was paid immediately.

The Court adjourned, Mr MacMillan told Mrs Thompson or any other Indian off the Reserve appear before the same Judge there would be no option, but a fixed sentence; we then returned to Hogansburg N.Y.

In the afternoon we again returned to the Village, Constable Tahamont still in Uniform, and saw Mr Taillon, in reference to warning the People about sending their children to school. Mr Taillon, was under the impression that I was to make prosecutions in regards to the different families who were not sending their children to school, explained to him my orders as I received them and warning "but I stated that if he thought it was necessary to be done by prosecution right away, that I would order to Cornwall, and get in touch with Supt Belcher Officer of "A" Division before I proceeded with the warning".

Taillon said that he thought it better to go ahead as I had received my instructions from the Dept. He then handed me a list of names of 12 different families, affecting some 30 children, who were not attending school. We then proceeded with Comst Tahamont, and made the rounds of these families, stating to them all, that if they did not send all their children, aged under 16 years of age, that in the course of 40 days or two weeks, there would be someone down to prosecute the heads of each family failing to do so, and would probably mean that the child in question would be taken away, and sent to the Spanish River school.

After completing the rounds, I made arrangements to meet Mr. Taillon at the school house on Cornwall Island, which is a part of the reserve. On Monday morning at 9:00 A.M., Jan 31st; we then proceeded from St. Regis Village to Gananoque, Ont., and from there across the river to Cornwall Ont., arriving at 7:00 P.M. Monday Dec 31st, accompanied by Rgt. No. 799E, Const Tahamont. I left Cornwall Ont. at 8:30 A.M., crossing the railway bridge on foot to Cornwall Island, where we hired a horse and cutter from an Indian living near the bridge, and then proceeded to the school house where we met Mr. Taillon, Indian Agent, who furnished us with a list of families who were not sending their children to school regularly on Cornwall Island—St. Regis and Yellow Island, which is all in the Reserve. This list included some 15 families on Cornwall Island, three families on St. Regis Island, and three families on Yellow Island, effecting some 44 children. After receiving this list from Mr. Taillon, he recommended one Peter Bay (Indian) on Cornwall Island, and six Policemen on the Reserve, to accompany us as a guide, and interpret to any one who could not talk the English language; I took this man for the day, and he was very satisfactory, as a large amount of the people we interviewed did not, or could not, talk English. We completed our work and returned to Ottawa about 6:30 A.M.

I have to state that in regard to the Indians living in the village of St. Regis, we, they took the warning all right, and promised to send their children to school; but on St. Regis Island, Yellow and Cornwall Island Ont., there was quite a lot of dissenting; some said that it was too far to go to school for small children, some having to go over two miles; and some said that it was no use sending their children to school, as they did not learn anything there, as the teacher was no good, and some various other complaints. But I told them that if they had any complaints against the teacher, or the way the school was run, they had better lay their complaints before Mr. Taillon the Indian Agent.

But I might state that there was one case which drew my particular attention; on my list there was included one Mr. Peter Belormer, who had 3 girls and one boy of school age, whom I interviewed and gave the regular warning; this woman is a widow, and has I think six small children up to the age of nine years of age, and two boys around 15 or 16 years of age; this woman told me it would be a godsend to have some of the children sent to the Spanish River school, as she is not able to clothe them warm enough to send them to school, which is about two miles away. This family looked to me to be in destitution.

Although there was quite a lot of talk about us being sent onto the Reserve, especially one man in Uniform, there was nothing unusual occurred.

On Tuesday morning Feb 1st, accompanied by Comst Tahamont, we left Cornwall Ont., via Ry, and Ottawa at 9:15 A.M., arriving in Ottawa at 11:45 A.M.

Sir,

Referring to yours of April 19, 1921, #33-6-1 regarding the trees planted this Spring for shade purposes in the grounds of St Regis Village School, I regret to be obliged to have to inform you that of the 25 trees set out only one has survived; this is to be regretted, I had hoped they would grow nicely and that in a few years we would have some beautiful shade trees.

The only reason that I can see for their not living is the fact that during June and July there was such a drought that there was not enough moisture in the ground to keep them moist until roots had become sufficiently strong.

Animals were not allowed on the grounds, therefore, the only cause for their not living was the dry weather.

Had I not been occupied taking the Federal Census at that time, possibly by sprinkling they might have been saved, yet the cost would have been greater than the setting out of other trees.

Sir:

I wish to refer to that portion of your letter of the 15th instant, in which you recommend that everything possible be done to make the instruction more attractive at the St. Regis Indian schools. Please instruct the teachers that the Department expects them to teach hand work to the younger pupils, to have sewing classes, and gymnastic exercises for all children and to give the older girls some instruction in sewing and related domestic science. Particularly in the Village School, there should be a determined effort to make the classroom and playground activity so interesting, that the children will enjoy their school day. The teachers should personally supervise the recess period, which should be at least 20 minutes in duration, and group games should be taught and practised. If any supplementary athletic equipment is required, please submit a requisition. Further, the Department will supply a small quantity of sewing material, yarn, etc., and any other aids considered advisable, upon request, and the teachers should devote one hour, twice a week during the regular class period, for the teaching of sewing, knitting, etc.

At each school, the teacher should immediately commence training and preparation for a school concert, which will be held at the end of the academic year in June and to which the parents should be invited. You may inform the teachers that the failure of any or all of them to comply with these instructions and to brighten up the teaching will be considered by the Department good and sufficient reason for their dismissal.
