MEMORANDUM FOR FILE:

February 1, 1927.

On Saturday, the 29th ultimo, I visited the St. Regis reserve, for the purpose of meeting the teachers and trying to straighten out several little difficulties in connection with the professional services. I explained to them that any teacher who could not work and live in harmony with the others on the reserve had a disturbing influence which would interfere with success in the classrooms. Miss E. Prudhomme, of Chetlain, handed in her resignation to take effect as soon as she could be relieved. I definitely placed Miss MacInulty in charge of the girls, both as far as their classroom activity was concerned and in their residence. I laid down the rule that the village residence was to be used by the Chetlain and Chenail teachers from Saturday until Sunday only and that they upon those occasions were to meet a fair share of the cost and to assist in the work. I arranged for the installation of Miss Carmel Dunnigan, the new teacher at St. Regis Island, who is to live with the two village teachers in the village residence. Mr. MacGibbon, the new Indian agent, is quite sincere and eager to do his best and I believe in time will be a good representative.

Sir:

Miss. F. Morris, teacher of St. Regis Village school, (junior room) report to me as follows:

On April 19th./28 I had occasion to retain some of my class in school after school hours, for certain work they neglected to finish during the day. Among the number kept in was Bernatine Oake. About 5 o'clock P.M., an older sister of Bernatine Oake who is not attending school, name Charlotte Oake, came to the school and wanted to know the reason why her sister was not coming home. I politely told her the reason. Charlotte Oake used slang at me; also on leaving the room told me "to go to ---". Regarding the above matter I visited Charlotte Oake, and informed her the seriousness of her actions, and advised her not to interfere with the teachers whatever, also that if she had any complaints to make, to report them to the agent. The above case should be dealt with, as it sets a very bad example to the school children, also the Indians should be taught to have nothing to do with the teachers whatever. Please advise me what action should be taken, or if any.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge your letter of the 15th inst. informing me that Miss Helena Dubois, teacher of the junior room, St. Regis Village Indian Day School, has resigned.

This is not altogether a surprise to me, although I had no knowledge of Miss Dubois intending to resign.

On January, 12th, if I recall the correct date, Miss Dubois came to me at the office, and complained of not being feeling well for some time previous, having a sore side, and said that she did not know whether she would be able to keep on teaching or not. I advised her that she had better see a doctor. On January, 13th, in the evening, Miss Dubois and Miss Mac Nulty went to Cornwall, and she, Miss Dubois was examined by a doctor (Dr. Gardner) as to the cause of the sore side. The doctor informed her that she had appendicitis, and advised her to discontinue teaching, go home and prepare herself for an operation. I may say that I did not know that Miss Dubois had went to a doctor, until yesterday, Jan. 19th, as they went over to Cornwall in the evening and returned the same evening.

Upon talking to Miss Dubois, in regards to resigning, she stated that she would not have resigned, if she was in good health. She also stated, that due to her health coupled with rather heavy class duties, that she resigned.

I have heard rumors, not from any of the teachers, but from outsiders, that the teachers residing at the residence find it rather hard at times to all agree, with respect to residential duties. Whether this reflects upon any one individual or not, I am not prepared to say. I do not interfere with private matters at the residence, as I don't think it would be good policy on my part, to do so.

We, the mothers of the children going to school here on the St. Regis Reservation, have to report to you the conduct of the teachers toward our children.

She has cruel ways of punishing the children in her care. First, she pounds them with her fists. Secondly, that they pull their ears, which has caused much concern. One of the children, that has had this treatment, has been ruined. He is still suffering from the effects.

Thirdly, that she uses ink rulers, which have an iron through it. They use this on the children's hands, which many times cause cuts & sores.

Fourthly, is that the teacher expels children from school until their noses to come back then they send for the Indian agent to go for them, when they have them back.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 8th instant, with reference to school matters, concerning St. Regis Village Indian Day School.

Referring to the matter in your letter, between Mabel Oake and Miss. Mac Donald, I beg to say, that I recall the incident.

Sometime in May, Mrs. Oake and daughter Mabel, called at the office (which was not the first time on school matters) complaining that the junior teacher, Miss. Mac Donald was ill using Mabel at school. That she had torn a dress that Mabel was wearing, and that she had struck Mabel with a stick or ruler.

A day or so later, I interviewed Miss. Mac Donald in the matter, and who denied of having struck Mabel at all, or having torn her dress.

It is pretty hard for me to doubt the teacher's word.

There has been so much wrangling and quarrelling going on at the village school and residence among the teachers for the past four-five months, that it is hard for me to say, who is at fault in this school matter.

One thing I do know is, that when I was first shown the dress that was supposed to be torn, I took note of the damage done. A few days later, I visited Mrs. Oakes residence, making further enquiry in the matter. The dress was again shown me, and I noticed that the dress was torn as much again, as when the first time it was shown me.

For me, I would not put too much stock in the Oake's story, for they have been causing trouble very frequently in one way or another, in school matters.

Of course, in the position I am in, I uphold the teacher as far as I can, for it would not do for me to side with the Indian in all school complaints, for if I did, it would not be long before many children would refuse to attend school, through their parents.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Buskard,

The Department has received the resignation of Miss Frances Morris, senior teacher of the St. Regis Village Day School - Reserve No. 15, Electoral District of Chateauguay-Huntingdon.

The St. Regis Village School is in the St. Regis Agency, and there are several other Indian schools in the same Agency. The teachers of these other schools, who have been in our employ for several years and regarding whose work very favourable reports have been received from the School Inspector, consider that, in view of the vacancy that has occurred, they are entitled to a promotion, and, consequently, I recommend for your approval the following changes:

(1) Miss Mary McDonald, at present teacher of the junior room in the St. Regis School, to be promoted to Principal;

(2) Miss Helen McRae, at present teacher of the St. Regis Island School, to be transferred to the St. Regis Village School, and placed in charge of the junior room;

(3) Miss Helena Fitzpatrick, at present teacher of the Chenail School, to be transferred to the St. Regis Island School.

The Church authorities request the appointment of Miss Frances Ursula Billings, teacher of the Chenail School. Miss Billings holds an Ontario Permanent Second Class certificate, together with an Elementary Agriculture certificate, Grade B Physical Training certificate, and Parts One of Elementary Arts and Household Science. (4) - Chatlain
(4) - Chatlain:

To Whom it may concern:

I'm now obliged to take this case up against the teacher, Miss Billings. She is going too far in beating children - similar case has happened previous to this - it was last winter in February. Dear Sir:

Re: Complaint - Mrs. Mary Mitchell

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of March 27th., with enclosure, a complaint against the teacher Miss Billings, of the Junior room, St. Regis Village Indian Day School.

Mrs. Mitchell visited at this office on the morning of Feb. 18/41, advising me of trouble between her daughter Annabelle and the teacher. She showed me her daughter's face, which was bruised on the cheek. I took the girl to the light of a large window. The bruise did not appear to be of a serious nature. Mrs. Mitchell would not visit the dispensary, saying, she would see her own doctor. She complained that the teacher had used her daughter too rough and that it was no way to whip a child, leaving bruises. I told her that I had a note from Miss Billings advising me that she had had trouble with one of her pupils, and, that I would investigate and learn just what the trouble was and the cause.

I visited the school in the company of the local R.C.M.P. Police officer, and learned of the happenings from the teacher and some of the children.

The teacher informed me that Annabelle Mitchell had taken her seat at 1:30 P.M. with her outdoor garments, coat, hat, etc., still on. She was asked to remove them, which she would not do. The teacher went to the girl's seat in an endeavour to have them removed, telling the girl she would receive a whipping if she did not obey. The girl still refused and would not hold her hand for the whipping. The teacher tried to whip her on the legs but the girl fought her. The teacher told me that the girl hit her in the face and kicked her on the legs. She tried to push the girl by standing her in the corner but the girl fought back and would not go. In the scuffle the girl pulled away from the teacher and the force threw her against the chalk trough of the black board.

I then turned to the class room and asked if any of the pupils who saw the trouble between the teacher and the Mitchell girl would tell me just what they saw, advising them not to be afraid and tell me the truth. Miss Billings made the remark to the effect that if I doubted her, I thought it best to hear what any of the children had to say.

Three children, Doris Standfield, Mabel Thomas and Cecelia Swamp, raised their hands and in turn corroborated the teacher's statement of what had happened. What I learned showed that the trouble was primarily the girl's fault, through disobedience, refusing to take punishment, fighting the teacher, and that the injury was not through a blow direct from the teacher.

R.A. Hoey, Esq.,
Supt. of Welfare and Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Can.
Later I followed up my investigation by a visit to the home of Mrs. Mitchell, who had refused to let her children attend school. I told her what I had learned and endeavored to show her that discipline in the school had to be maintained; that unruly children allowed to carry on unpunished would soon disrupt the whole class.

Mrs. Mitchell appeared to concur in the views I expressed and when I left she agreed that her children would return to school. She seemed satisfied with my investigation, and the matter appeared to be settled. The trouble did not seem to me serious enough for a special report to the Department.

I have not had any complaints by other parents about the teacher. Her class work has been very good and discipline, with the exception of this instance and one previously with the same girl, has been excellent. The other instance referred to happened, as near as I can recollect, during October 1939. In my absence, Mr. Harris, who was constable here then, went after this girl who ran away from her class. Advising me about it he said the girl had fought him all the way back to the school. He advised the teacher that she was a bad girl and deserved a good whipping.

I did not have one complaint while Miss Billings was teaching at the Chenaill school. Of course, the children of the village school contain some who are more or less unruly. Probably this is natural as they are more congregated. But I would not say there is undue trouble in this way.

I would sum this affair up as just an incident that might happen to any teacher in the correction of any unruly pupil. It is too bad that such things happen, but they have a way of cropping up.

You ask if it would be necessary for an official of the Department to investigate the conduct of Miss Billings and conditions generally in connection with the village school.

The conditions in connection with the village school have been very good, they have been under good management. I would not think there is any such condition that warrants an investigation by an official of the Department.

As regards the conduct of Miss Billings, on and off the Reserve. The conduct of Miss Billings on the reserve has been all that one would expect from any lady. As to her conduct off the Reserve, I have heard, neither do I know of anything detrimental to her character. Naturally one would expect a person so situated on an Indian Reserve, to find some association and recreation off the reserve, but as long as such does not affect the prestige of a teacher or the proper performance of her duties, they should be considered as personal and private. I have suggested that Miss Billings take this angle up with your office herself.

I note that Mrs. Mitchell says that the teacher was absent for three continuous days.

Mrs. Mitchell...........
Mrs. Mitchell is absolutely in error. Our records do not show such to be the case. Attendance report shows Miss Billing absent 14 days during the last quarter. We have no copy of the teacher's quarterly report but your copy could be checked for verification. If such were the case, it could not pass unnoticed as I have one child attending the Sr. room and the local R.C.M.P. officer has one child attending the Jr. room, of the village school.

In passing I notice that you refer to a statement signed by Claude Hall M.D. which as advised, was not enclosed with your letter.

I hope that this report covers the matter as fully as you require and that it serves your purpose.

Juvenile Court Judge Andre REGNEIR stating that he would pass sentence that date at the same time remarking that it would not be necessary for Mr. BONAPARTE and the undersigned to be present on that date, at that time it appeared that it was only a matter of decision which institution the boy should be committed to. Late PM, of the 16th Inst I was advised that Mr Ostiguy Sheriff of Valleyfield had called while I was out regarding the case. REPORT ON ST. REGIS AGENCY FOR MONTH OF JANUARY, 1943.

SCHOOLS

Schools reopened on January 4th., throughout the Agency. Attendance during the month has been very good considering weather conditions. Difficulty was experienced in finding seating capacity for children attending some of the schools but this situation has been remedied towards the close of the month. By switching some double seats to some of the schools and making replacements with singles it has been found possible to make seating room available at all schools. At St. Regis Village Jr. room and Cornwall Island Wes., while seating in now available, there are really too many children attending for one teacher to handle and yet accomplish the work set out in the curriculum.

D.P. McNaughton,
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA, Can.

On January 5th., 1940 we wrote you concerning Miss Terrance, teacher, who is now employed at the Chenail School. In this letter we outlined the difficulties experienced by this teacher in getting to and from her work while at the village school since she was not apparently very welcome at the village teachers' residence.

The situation this winter for this particular teacher is, to say the least, many times worse than when she taught at the village school. This being due to the severe weather experienced throughout this region all during the winter to date. The results being that she has missed school on many occasions and will no doubt be unable to get to the Chenail school from her home quite often during the remaining term. The family car, which her sister used to drive her from home to St. Regis has been wrecked for some time now and many times this teacher has had to walk this distance which is approximately five miles one way. There is no place that Miss Terrance can live on the reserve and be nearer her school with the exceptions of the teachers' residence in the village. It is difficult to tell Miss Terrance that she is not wanted there but such is certainly the case and has been told me in no uncertain terms despite the information contained in yours of Jan.9/40 which has been conveyed to the present staff of the village school.

As Miss Terrance has asked me to find a place for her to stay in the village and I am unable to get Miss McDonald to even see the thing in a reasonable light, I would ask your immediate direction in the matter as I do not wish to place anyone in such an embarrassing position as Miss Terrance is bound to find herself should she sleep at the residence under the present circumstances. Miss Terrance intends to take her meals at a local Indian home.
homes, so it is not a question of eating at the residence. At least that is what I am given to understand.

Incidentally I might mention that I have been advised by Miss McDonald that if Miss Terrance come to the residence I would have two teachers to find. On the other hand when I put the question to Miss Caza, the remaining teacher at the residence she replied "Oh sure, Yes" in reply to whether she would be agreeable to having Miss Terrance at the residence.

Under the circumstances I do not feel I should act in the matter until further direction from your office.

R.A. Hoey, Esq. Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Re: Freeman Jacobs AND Lawrence Benedict

The above are children attending the Junior Room of the St. Regis Village School. Jacobs is 13 and Benedict is 12 years of age. Both should have been out of the Junior room long ago.

During the past four years I have had to reprimand young Jacobs for various acts of misbehaviour. He is a ring-leader in everything that pertains to deviltry at school and away from school. So far, with this exception, Benedict has kept out of trouble.

Last week at the village school, while the Principal and Cat. Meagher RCMP, left the Junior room, these young boys exposed their person to the entire class of small children numbering about 30 pupils. It is our understanding that Freeman Jacobs did the act first and prompted Benedict to follow him. Peter Jacobs, the father, has whipped this boy on many occasions but he never appears to profit any. This boy's mother has left the household some months ago and the father is left with small children. To earn a living he is away from the reserve mostly the entire day.

As this sort of behaviour cannot be tolerated at school I would recommend that the R.C.M.P. Police be authorized to take Jacobs before the Juvenile Court at Valleyfield and that a recommendation be made to the court to place this boy in a corrective institution for at least one year. For the benefit of the Court it should be mentioned that the Department will defray expenses of this boy's maintenance in the institution confined. In the course of a few days you will receive a detailed report from the R.C.M.P. on this case.

It will be noted in some cases very low average for December. This is due to the flu epidemic mostly. In general it can be said that attendance at the various schools has maintained a high level. Such a high percentage is particularly noteworthy at the Chenail school where it was difficult to get the boys to school. The reverse is now the case as far as the boys are concerned. With the exception of the Cornwall Island East school no manual training is carried on. The village boys get the benefit of some training along this line when such is possible with the time at the disposal of the local constable. With only one man now stationed here less time can be devoted to such work among the boys. Due to the poor freezing of the St. Lawrence this winter it has not been possible during December to get to St. Regis Island School. Ice conditions are such that it is not safe to walk nor can a boat be used. Only emergency trips are made by the Indian residents of the island.

In general the children on the whole appear to be well-behaved and industrious. There is very little incentive for those children in our Quebec schools to devote much energy to studies after they reach the age of 15 as the prospect of being able to attend a high school is no better than in most years. The hard period to keep those children at school is between the age of 15 and 16. The boys in particular just wont exert themselves too much after 15. This situation is most unfortunate as they have just reached a point in life when they should be capable of absorbing some knowledge. I feel though that if we could give them the kind of training they would like at this period we would be well repaid and would not have any attendance problem on our hands to contend with.

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of June 11th concerning teaching of Domestic Science, etc., at the St. Regis Village Day School. There is no doubt but that the teaching of the subject under consideration by Sister Zita would be most beneficial to the children of the Village School. As you know, a limited amount of work was done along these lines up to 3 or 4 years ago. I note, however, that the subject under consideration would appear to apply only to the girls of the Village School and that consideration has not been given to Manual Training exercises for the boys. Concerning the latter, I might advise you that Constable Gillis is no longer with us and I am unable, myself, to devote any attention to the young boys going to school.

I do not think that any question has been raised regarding the building of an additional class-room. Personally, I would not even make a suggestion along these lines without giving the matter much thought as I am not in favour of the present school location whatever. You are probably aware that the band has purchased a building near our office and that I have it equipped to serve the needs of our Homemakers' Clubs as well as some of the activities of the children. If arrangements could be made with the Welfare officials to use the equipment for cooking I have no objection to the Sister's using this building for Home Economics or any other classes. Insofar as a music teacher is concerned, there certainly is plenty of room for one here and music should form a very important part of the curriculum of Indian Education.

It is possible that with the arrangement outlined above the services of an additional teacher at the Village School could be utilized and while I would like to see a little more attention given to the boys, it is very difficult under such an arrangement.

I have discussed the above very thoroughly with Sister Zita and she advises that with the services of an additional teacher, who also knows music, she would not object to taking over as far as she is able Manual Training classes with the boys. In this respect, it might be possible for them to follow the course outlined some time ago by Mr. Doucet.
It must be remembered, however, that the object of trying to find such a location such as is used by our Homemakers' Clubs was to create a community centre and not to take the place of a class-room. I do not think any objection could be raised to use this building 2 half-days per week or one full day for school purposes.

As for teaching Domestic Science, Sewing and Home Economics, etc., at St. Regis, the need is great but as to the employment of suitable personnel for such a task, I will leave it to your discretion.

Dear Sir:

We have recently adopted a new teachers' salary schedule. In this schedule we classify our teachers as holding either

(a) Second Class teaching certificates,
(b) First Class teaching Certificates,
(c) High School teachers' Certificates.

Naturally, the salaries vary in accordance with the qualifications.

We have had considerable difficulty in assessing qualifications of some of our teachers. We require, for a second class certificate, at least three years of high school plus a year at a teacher training establishment. For a first class certificate we require at least four years of high school (or one year university plus one year at a teacher training establishment). In the Province of Quebec, we would appreciate hearing from you as to the correlation between your Normal Schools and the various Universities. The attached letter has been received from the Directress of Studies of the Sisters of St. Ann. The point at issue is whether the Sisters concerned hold a teaching certificate or license from your province. We are quite definite in requiring such a license or certificate for classification on our scale.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Henry,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Ottawa, August 17, 1935.

Madam:

I have to inform you that the Department has approved of your transfer, from the position as teacher of the junior room in the St. Regis Village School, to the principalship of the St. Regis Village Indian Day School for the coming school year, to replace Miss Frances Morris, who resigned. The salary allowed you will be at the rate of $106.00 per teaching month. You should arrange to begin duties when the school re-opens after the present holidays, on September third, next. It is hoped that you will meet with every success in the work.

Besides the teaching duties, you will be in charge of the teachers' residence and will be held responsible for the care and management. You will be expected to maintain a spirit of cooperation among those living in the residence.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. Mackenzie,
Secretary.

Miss Mary McDonald,
29 Argyle Avenue,
Ottawa, Ont.

Memo to Treasury Branch re above on No. 3 After Day School Morn.
Ottawa, June 28th, 1937.

Dear Sir,-

On Saturday, June 26th, this Department mailed five letters containing cheques for the teachers on the St. Regis Indian Reserve. These cheques should not have been sent as the schools closed on Friday last, and the teachers arrived in Ottawa today en route to their homes.

As these letters will likely be in your post office awaiting the Wednesday mail for St. Regis, I would appreciate very much if you would re-address them. This would enable the teachers to receive the cheques at a much earlier date than if they are sent to St. Regis and re-addressed from there.

The letters to which I refer are as follows:-

To be addressed to:-

Miss Helena Fitzpatrick - c/o Bank of Montreal,

Ottawa, Ont.

Miss H. C. McRea - c/o Royal Bank,
Alexandria, Ont.

Miss F. U. Billings - 151 Gloucester St.,
Ottawa, Ont.

Miss G. Legarde - 403 Third St.,
Cornwall, Ont.

I trust that you will be able to make the above arrangements.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,

GENERAL REMARKS.

I am sorry to report poor lumber in the floor and wainscoting. It is too bad to spoil a job by putting in unseasoned lumber in the finishings. All the joints have opened and much cold is admitted on this account. The contractor who built the buildings should be charged for putting in green and unseasoned lumber where it is so important to have kiln dried ceiling and flooring. I would not accept such work if I were the architect.

Sgd. A. Luther Gilman, B.A.
Ottawa, February 28, 1912.

Gentlemen,

The Department regrets to have to call your attention to the fact that the lumber supplied by you last summer for repairs to the school on St. Regis Island was not up to the standard. It was not properly seasoned and the Public School Inspector reports that as a result the joints are parted to the extent of from one-half to one inch in some places.

I may also say that a similar complaint in regard to the interior woodwork in the new school in the village of St. Regis has been received.

The Department has no doubt that you were not aware of the fact that the lumber furnished was not properly seasoned and has no doubt that you will be willing to make the necessary reparation. I shall be glad to hear from you in regard to these matters.

Your obedient servant,

Assistant Deputy and Secretary.

Messrs. Ross & Co.,
Cornwall, Ont.

Dear Sir:

I beg to hand you particulars and copy of a claim of $37.83 which John L. Thompson a Canadian Indian and a member of the St.Regis Band living at St.Regis Quebec, has against Angus Lalonde a Building Contractor here.

Mr. Lalonde has a contract with your Department for building a side-walk and a fence at the Indian School House at St.Regis, and also for building a fence at the Indian School House on St.Regis Island. He employed this John L. Thompson to furnish him with the sand and do the work and pay the men, all as set out in the enclosed. But, he is either refusing or neglecting to pay Thompson this money and Thompson called on me last Saturday afternoon - 19th instant - and asked me to present the account to you so that he may be protected, if possible, by you. The various services are all under separate items.

Thompson is poor and actually needs this money for himself and his little family.

I concluded it would be a saving of money for Thompson to send this claim direct to you rather than to take proceedings. If there are any suggestions you could make me in this regard, I would be obliged.

Yours respectfully,

Ottawa, February 28th., 1916.

Sir,-

I beg to say that the Department is in receipt of a letter from a legal firm in Cornwall on behalf of John Thompson, a St. Regis Indian. Sir,

The school year approaches its end and another school term arrives. I have to ask you with all the energy I possess to enlarge during the present vacation, the St. Regis village school.

I might write several pages explaining the necessity of such a move but I know full well that the deficiency is one of the excellent attendance at this school for some time and that for the number of pupils attending it has become altogether too small.

Take for the last year our average had never fallen lower than 38 and has been as high as 51 and, for very good reasons we fully expect to surpass that average.

The only manner by which the Indians can be made an important factor able to compete with the white man and to take his place alongside of his white brother is by education; there is not any...
Sir,

The system whereby the Indians can be improved is also among the provisions to 1910. The attendance for the schools was very good and by all appearances I do not think the attendance will lessen in the future but on the contrary, should increase.

The cost of running this school would be insignificant amount when weighed with the great amount of good that it does for these people.

Again, with two rooms a teacher covered how much time she devotes to her field as she moved naturally from a smaller class and this moved into her more efficient and most certainly a smaller class should progress more rapidly than a larger one.

Hoping you will take immediate action and not delay action one of my aspirations for the improvement of our Indians.

REPORT OF INSPECTOR A.L. GILMAN ON THE ST. REGIS VILLAGE SCHOOL.

THE JUNIOR ROOM,

The building and outhouses are no longer suitable for school purposes. The school building is less than one-third as large as it should be to accommodate the pupils attending. Consequently hygienic conditions are necessarily very bad. Ventilation is the very worst.

A new building should be ready for this larger number of pupils before the re-opening next autumn. I would strongly advise a wing or addition to the village senior school, making room for a graded school under a senior and junior teacher. The grading would be better and greater efficiency would obtain.

Date of Inspection, June 6th and 8th, 1917.
Ottawa, July 10, 1917.

Sir,

I am sending you, under separate cover, a plan of the addition which it is proposed to make to the St. Regis Village School in order to provide accommodation for all the children who should attend this school.

The Department would like you to state whether you think this work could be done by day labour or whether tenders should be called for. Kindly advise the Department at once in regard to this matter, as the work should be started as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

J. B. McLean

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

F. E. Taillon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
St. Regis, Que.
Referring to your of July 10th enclosed, # 151938/5, regarding addition to St Regis Village School, I beg to state that I think the work could be properly carried out by day labour, provided, of course, that Mr. Cherr or some one from the Department undertook to superintend the work; I would consider the work should be done cheaper this way than by contract.

Hoping an early start may be made upon this much needed work.

J. D. McLean, Sec.
Ottawa, Ont.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

Herewith, under separate cover, please find plans and specifications for the addition to the St. Regis Indian Day School.

It is proposed to purchase the materials by tender and have the work carried out by day labour, under your supervision, providing you are prepared to give the work the necessary attention. The assistance of a competent, practical man, as working foreman, would be provided that the work would be under constant supervision and carried on with diligence at all times. The necessary supervision from the Department will be given when this is considered necessary.

It is proposed to utilize competent Indian labour from the reserve to as large an extent as possible, providing this is available at current wages there, and other labour necessary at the lowest price current in the locality.

A bill of quantities for the lumber, etc., will be forwarded to you within a few days, on which tenders should be taken from dealers in that vicinity and forwarded to the Department for consideration before action is taken. The materials for basement, such as stone, sand.

Memorandum

Mr. Scott,

The Indian School at St. Regis will provide accommodation for 36 children with a minimum of air space. There are enrolled there 68 pupils with an average attendance of 50, accommodation for the excess being provided by the use of an old building which does not afford the necessary accommodation and is now unfit for school purposes.

Plans have been prepared enlarging the existing school, providing an additional room which will fully meet their requirements.

As it is a difficult matter to procure tenders at this time for the erection of a building at a reasonable price, it is proposed to purchase the material and erect the building by day labour, the labour being available on the reserve and in that vicinity.

Tenders for the materials have been requested through Mr. F.E. Taillon, Indian Agent, there, bills of quantities having been submitted to the dealers in the vicinity.
The following tenders have been received:

Atchison & Company, $1644.36
St. Lawrence Lumber & Box Co., South Lancaster,
$35.00 per M for green lumber.

Referring to the recent visit of Mr. Christie relative to drainage of school, I regret to say that I am unable to get anyone to tender for the work.

The grounds should receive some attention this spring.

Ottawa, February 21, 1921.

Sir,

Mr. Inspector Gilman, in a report on his recent inspection of the St. Regis Village Indian Day School, states that the school grounds should receive some attention this coming spring and that they should be made more attractive to the children, as an example to be followed at their homes. He recommends that trees, shrubs and flowers should be planted and cared for by the teachers and pupils.

I should be pleased to have your views regarding the Inspector's recommendation. It is thought that the Indians themselves should arrange for the planting of some trees and shrubs on the school grounds. If you agree with the Inspector's recommendation, you should also state what you consider it would cost to have the work done and, if trees, shrubs, etc., were planted, whether they would receive proper attention.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

F. E. Taillon, Esq.,
Indian Agent,

The buildings are in good repair except the water closets which need repairs to the doors.

Ottawa, December 3rd, 1925.

Sir:

A request has been received from the Principal of the St. Regis Village Indian Day School for a grant to purchase supplies for a Christmas tree and concert to be held in the Village school for the pupils of that school and the St. Regis Island, Chetlain and Chenail Schools. During the past, the Department has allowed a grant for the purpose of providing the children with a treat either at Christmas or midsummer. We are allowing a grant in the present instance for the schools in your Agency as follows, viz:

St. Regis Village School... $12.00,
St. Regis Island "... 5.00,
Chetlain School........... 5.00,
Chenail "... ............ 5.00,
Cornwall Island School.... 5.00.

You should consult the teachers as to the supplies they require, and either you or the teachers themselves can arrange for the purchase. The above authorized amount in each case is not to be exceeded.

Accounts, in duplicate, should be obtained from the merchant from whom the supplies are purchased. These you should attach to proper voucher forms, certify in the usual manner and send to the Department for payment. If possible, vouchers covering the expenditure for each of the schools separately should be forwarded.

We have many calls at this season of the year for grants to provide treats to the children at our Indian schools, and the above authorized amounts are all that we can provide for the schools in the St. Regis Agency. Please advise the teachers accordingly and assist them in every way you can in making their Christmas tree and concert a success.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Sir,

A blackboard for the use of one of the Indian Schools conducted by this Department on the St. Regis Reserve, Province of Quebec, was recently shipped from L. Leblanc, Montreal, Que., addressed to E. Casa, Nyando, N.Y.

Nyando, N.Y., is the closest point to our Day School and it is much more convenient for supplies to be delivered to the school from this point than from any point in Canada.

You will note that this blackboard was intended for an Indian School in Canada and was simply passing through the United States. I believe, therefore, that no duty should have been charged. Would it be possible to arrange a refund to this Department?

The Collector of Customs,

Sir:

The Department refers to your letter of December 16, 1926 (73077), in regard to the duty assessed upon a blackboard addressed to E. Casa, Nyamio, N.Y., and covered by Malone entry No. B-307 of October 2, 1926.

It appears that the blackboard in question was shipped from Montreal and was intended for the use of one of the Indian schools of the Department of Indian Affairs of Canada on the St. Regis Reserve in the province of Quebec. It was, however, sent to Nyamio for the reason that this was the closest point to this day school and that it was much more convenient for supplies to be delivered to the school from Nyamio than from any point in Canada.

It, therefore, appears that the article in question was in fact in transit from a point in Canada through the United States to another point in Canada; that it was sent to this country as a matter of shipping convenience only, and that, had the United States customs regulations governing in transit goods been complied with, it would not have been considered an importation into this country and no entry would have been required.

In view of the foregoing, you are hereby authorized to cancel the consumption entry made in this case, to treat the goods in question as having been in transit and to make refund accordingly of the duty paid.

Respectfully,

(Signed) L.C. Andrews

I beg to say regarding voucher No. 60, amounting to $75.00 in favour of John Day, for painting the exterior of St. Regis Village School. John Day and Peter Johnson took this job of painting, price $70.00. They both worked about a week, when Peter Johnson fell ill on account of illness. In the meantime John Day hired Peter Thomas to help him until Johnson returned. They finished putting on the first coat, which took a great deal longer than they expected. John Day came to me and said that they were not going to make fair wages at that price. I knew myself that $70.00 was a low price for putting on two coats on a large building like this one, so I told Mr. Day to go ahead and put on the second coat that I would raise the price to $75.00. I was anxious to get this painting done, so they started the second. I may say that the first coat on this building took a tremendous lot of paint, as this building had not been painted for some years. The arrangement on the start was that John Day was to receive the cheque, and he pay his men, which I am sure Mr. Day will do.

Mr. John Day is nearly finished the painting of the interior of this building. Price agreed on $63.00.

I Am,

Your Obedient Servant,

W.G. MacGibbon

I hereto say that the new shed at St. Regis Village School, which Atchison & Co of Cornwall, Ont. was authorized to construct, is completed. This shed is very strongly built, having a two inch plank floor, a bin petitioned off for coal, room for wood, and room for storing desks. I had Angus Oak remove the coal which was left over from the previous year, also wood, to the new shed, which he charged $2.00. October 24th./27.

Sir,-

I beg to say regarding St. Regis Village School. The basement of this school has been filled in according to your instructions. There are seven basement windows, a lot of these windows are broken, that is the glass in them, and have been broken for some time. As these windows are even with the ground, they are very easily broken by the children playing, unless there are heavy wire screens put on to protect them. As the basement of this school will not be used for any purpose anymore, I would suggest to have these windows cemented in even with the foundation of the school wall, leaving one window for air when needed.

John L. Thompson, of St. Regis Village would do this job, six windows $24.00. $4.00 per window.

If this was done it would be far easier to keep the class-rooms heated in cold weather. Trusting that you will see fit to authorize me to have this work done.

I Am

Your Obedient Servant,

W.C. Mac Gibbon
Agent.

The Secretary,
Department Of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Ottawa, October 29, 1927.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 24th instant, in which you recommend that 6 of the basement windows of the St. Regis Day School building be cemented in even with the foundation of the school wall, and stating that you can have this work carried out at a cost of approximately $24.

In reply I beg to say that you may arrange with John L. Thompson to do this work, and you may also arrange to have a wire screen placed over the window which is left open in order to air the basement. Please arrange to have this work completed at an early date. When the work has been completed, you should forward a properly certified voucher, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred.

I have also your letter of the 15th instant, in which you recommend that the two closets and the new shed be painted. You may arrange with John Day to give the shed two coats of paint and the closets one coat of paint. We note that he will do this work for the sum of $5. This work should be completed before the extreme cold weather sets in. An account, in duplicate, properly certified, should be forwarded covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ottawa, October 26, 1928.

Madam:

I have your letter of the 22nd instant, stating that you are planning to have a school garden, next spring, at the St. Regis Village Indian Day School, and enquiring if the Department would pay for the services of someone to look after the garden during the summer vacation. In reply I beg to say that the Department is not prepared to approve of the payment of someone to look after this garden during the holidays. Further, it is not the policy of the Department to allow any produce, grown in school gardens, to be used for any other purposes than for the use of the teachers or of the Indian pupils who assist in the work. If you conduct a garden next spring, it may be that you could arrange with the agent to have the oversight of same during the vacation.

The Department regrets that there are no funds available for the purpose of supplying a piano for the use of the school. We will allow any small expense required in the putting on of a Christmas entertainment for the pupils and will also allow a small grant to purchase gifts or other supplies for the purpose.
